title: Long read | Debunking myths on links between austerity and Brexit

last_post.content:
A great example of some quite blatant misreading of data is posted below.

This was in 2019. Rob Ford claimed that classic #Brexit voters and supporters - UKIP voters - wanting more #austerity

This is just false. As I explain at length here (https://blogs.lse.ac.uk/brexit/2019/10/17/long-read-debunking-myths-on-links-between-austerity-and-brexit/)
#UKIP voters, to a tiny extent disliked #austerity a bit less than the rest.

Misreading data and quick analysis can lead to such wrong conclusions producing noise that benefited those behind #austerity and #Brexit project.

Today our team launched the @astro rebuild of https://mijnvraagovercorona.nl 🎉

Originally the website was built using Next.js with a lighthouse performance score of ~73. Now we score 99:
LCP 3.8s -> 1s
TTI 5.4s -> 3.3s
TBT 420ms -> 80ms
CLS 0.127 -> 0.008.
Tweaking of 3rd party scripts should get us the full 💯💯💯💯

With the rebuild we could also focus on some accessibility painpoints. It's not perfect yet, but we're actively working on it. 🙌🏼

last_post.content:
I've been working on new foundational crates for #BonsaiDb's storage layer.

#OkayWAL is the crate I'll highlight today. It's a write-ahead log (WAL) implementation for #RustLang. It's far from stable, but as of today, it is now feature complete as far as my initial concept is concerned.

A WAL's goal is to get bits describing the changes being made to a #database to disk as quickly as possible while being ACID-compliant.

It's easy to adapt to different settings. It gives a variance-weighted ATE, but it's easy to re-weigh to get an equally-weighted ATE.

title: The tragedy of the commons is a false and dangerous myth | Aeon Essays

last_post.content:
The tragedy of the commons is a pernicious myth.

The demise of the commons of Britain and Europe wasn't the result of misuse by commoners, but enclosing by the landowners. The original hypothetical was made up for storytelling purposes, and the term was popularized by an ecologist with anti-immigrant and racist views.

Here is my recommended reading for heading into 2023:

After Ahrens’ book I see an awful lot of people talking about “processing” books. There are too many assumptions about what this can mean and this hides many levels of inherent work involved in analyzing and synthesizing knowledge. I would suggest that we’re better off talking about reading them, annotating, excerpting, and thinking about them, or maybe writing about and combining them with other knowledge than “processing” them.

"What should I measure when the CEO asks for engineering metrics?" is probably the most frequently recurring eng leadership question, and connects into a larger, somewhat nebulous topic: how should you measure engineering organizations?

The biggest challenge with answering this question directly imo is that there are a number of different stakeholders who all want very different things. Literal answers anchor on one stakeholders rather than solving for whole set.

title: GitHub - andrewwillmott/sun-sky: Various sun/sky models, convolution of theta/gamma-parameterised models

last_post.content:
@dougbinks @floooh @srekel "clear sky model" is a useful google term, and "A Practical Analytic Model for Daylight" is a classic paper that includes references to foundational work from Nishita et al. These days there're more recent models from Wilkie's group, and lots of work on simulating scattering directly rather than modelling it.

You might find https://github.com/andrewwillmott/sun-sky useful.

Also https://www.scratchapixel.com/lessons/procedural-generation-virtual-worlds/simulating-sky/simulating-colors-of-the-sky.html is a great introduction.
